repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Grants for Disaster
            Hazard Mitigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Disaster Hazard Mitigation Project
            for the Kyrgyz Republic had an overall moderately
            satisfactory outcome, with the performances of the Bank and
            the borrower being deemed moderately satisfactory as well.
            Of the four project development objectives indicators
            (PDOs), two were fully achieved, one was incompletely
            achieved, and one indicator was dropped. Of the four
            intermediate outcome indicators, two were achieved, while
            the remaining indicators were dropped. The following
            significant lessons were learned during the implementation
            of the project: 1) communication and community participation
            are key elements in the design, implementation and
            sustainability of natural hazards and environmental
            liability remediation projects; 2) PDOs and key performance
            indicators are crucial; 3) the importance of involving
            international or national experienced specialists from
            preparation to closure; 4) early development of the plans to
            close the mine tailings and waste dumps, stop relocation
            works, based on risk assessment and design of covering,
            drainage and vegetation measures should be part of initial
            engineering planning; and 5) the time necessary for the
            preparation and implementation of relatively complex
            projects from a technical, institutional and communication
            point of view should not be underestimated.

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Disaster Hazard
            Mitigation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Disaster Hazard Mitigation Project for the Kyrgyz Republic
            is to: a) minimize the exposure of humans, livestock, and
            fluvial flora and fauna to radionuclide's associated
            with abandoned uranium mine tailings and waste rock dumps in
            the Mailuu-Suu area; b) improve the effectiveness of
            emergency management and response by national and
            sub-national authorities and local communities to disaster
            situations; and c) reduce the loss of life and property in
            key landslide areas of the country. The reallocation is
            necessary as the volume of civil works and consultancy
            services is higher than originally estimated due to
            increased quantities of radioactive tailings having to be
            relocated from Tailings Management Facility (TMF) 03. The
            current reallocation contains a small deviation from the
            request from the Ministry of Finance in order to match the
            revised amounts in the land and property and incremental
            operating costs categories with the amounts actually
            disbursed. This deviation has been approved by Ministry of
            Finance on March 20, 2012. This will be the second extension
            of the closing date and is expected that completion of the
            works, including the relocation of the additional 38,000

Kyrgyz Republic - Disaster Hazard
            Mitigation Project : restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Additional Financing for
            the Disaster Hazard Mitigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Additional Financing for the Disaster Hazard Mitigation
            Project for the Kyrgyz Republic is to: a) minimize the
            exposure of humans, livestock, and fluvial flora and fauna
            to radionuclide's associated with abandoned uranium
            mine tailings and waste rock dumps in the Mailuu-Suu area;
            b) improve the effectiveness of emergency management and
            response by national and sub-national authorities and local
            communities to disaster situations; and c) reduce the loss
            of life and property in key landslide areas of the country.
            The additional funds will enable repairing the flood damage
            inflicted during project implementation on crucial road
            infrastructure necessary for the transport of radioactive
            materials. Furthermore, the Additional Finance (AF) will
            also contribute to the relocation of additional volumes of
            radioactive waste rock from Waste Dump 1 (WD1), which were
            discovered during project implementation up to date, as well
            as the continued relocation of radioactive tailings from
            Tailings Pond Number 3 (TP3). Lastly, the AF will support
            monitoring activities for strengthening capacities of
            measuring uranium and other toxicological elements in
            various water resources. The AF does not affect the
            project's development objective.
